REPORT, 1881-1882.
INTRODUCTORY.
Phe subject matter contained in this report and ombm*
the accompanying tables covers in detail the transactions of this
office for the term ending November 30, A. D. 1883; and the
onvenient form in which all statistical matter is arranged and
placed before your Excellency, will enable you to more clearly
inform yourself officially of the doings in this branch <>f the
Executive Department of our State for the period since the dat<* of the last biennial report of the Secretary of State.
It will be observed by your Excellency in a careful perusal oi
its pages, that from the increased amount of work performed
that the work of this office, and the varied duties which devolvt
upon the Secretary of State, that his duties have very materially
increased daring the past two yean.
This tact will be better evidenced by a reference by you to th<ibdivision of this report entitled "Fees,"' wherein it is shown that
the sums received by this office for work performed has mor
than doubled in amount that received for any prenOM two y. ars
since the office was created.
I would also invite vour attention to the WTenU recommenda-
tions incorporated in my report, the deductions as made therein
beiqg the result of an experieeec and practical knowledge of the
subjects discussed.
COMPILED STAT1TKS, SESSION' LAWS AND JOURNALS.
At the sixteenth session of the Legislature all the public a -ts then in force, including the revision of 1866, and the acts of a general nature passed at said session, were ordered compiled and put into chapters with appropriate heads and titles, with marginal references to the decisions of the Supreme Court. This compila-

tiou, as the law directed, was published by Hon. Guy A. Brown, State Librarian, and the copies thereof were purchased by the State at two dollars and tifty cents per copy, an appropriation of eight thousand seven hundred and titty dollar! being made by the Legislature for the purchase of thirty-five hundred (3500) copies of these said statutes.
The act containing this appropriation also included an item diraeting copies of this oomptled edition of the statutes should be distributed bj the Secretary of State to the same officers as the iTeiieral statute:- of Nebraska tor 1873 were so distributed.
Agreeably to this provision of law, I have the honor to submit herewith an itemized statement showing the number of statutes of 1881 delivered to each county, and for which legal requisition has been made upon this office. In this connection will also be found the number of session laws of 1881, the extra session of
f2, the journals of both Houses of the Legislature for 1881, the extra session of 1882, which have placed in the hands of several county clerks for distribution, as the law requires.

SKCRKTARY OP STATE.
Provision is made under the present law on this subject tor an annual enumeration of the inhabitants of this State, but since the Ieral enumeration of 1880 was made the counties have not all onded thereto, and a full and complete 'return for the years I and 1882 cannot be made in this report, the provisions of law are believed by competent legal authority to be in full e and effect, yet with all, a rigid enforcement of its provisions Id seem like working a hardship upon the counties who have unable to bear the expense which which would necessarily nd the taking of the same. The wording of the constituis such that an enumeration of the inhabitants of the State
should be made in the year 1885, and every ten years therealter; such being the case, I can see no reason why the present law should not be repealed, thus relieving the counties from an obligation not intended by the frarnera of our constitution.
Moreover, it is believed that when the proper time arrives for the taking of a census for 1885 a law can be drafted that will be more practicable in its effect and contain less of the incongruities and defects that the present law has been noted for.
As a matter of statistical information I have appended herewith a table showing the number of inhabitants by counties, the State has contained from the year 1855 down to the present time, less the counties who have made no report thereunder:

SECRETARY OF KATE.
PUBLIC PRINTING.
Under the provisions of Section 4, Article 2, of Chapter 83 ol the Compiled Statutes of 1881, in connection with other official duties devolving upon the Secretary of State, it is made a part of the work of this office to report to your Bxeelfoncj a schedule of the prices paid by the State for its several classes of public printing under the several contracts, as the case may be. awarded by the State under the present law M thai subject.
I have therefore caused to be appended herewith in appropriate form a copy 'of the schedule of prices paid for the past two years, viz: 1881 and 1882, also the same matter similarly arranged for the forthcoming two years, viz: 1883 and 1884, and as awarded by the State Printing Board of Audit at a meeting of said Board on the 6th day of December, 1882, at whicli time proposals wore received as follows :
On Class One, from the State Journal Co., of Lincoln, Henry Gibson, Omaha, and the Tribune Printing Co., Lincoln.
On Class Two, State Journal Co., Henry Gibson, Tribune Printing Company and C. E. Yost.
On Class Three, State Journal Co.. Henry Gibson, Tribune Printing Co*, and C. E. Yost.
On Class Four, State Journal Co., Henry Gibson, Tribune Printing Co. and C. E. Yost.
On Class Five. State Journal Co. Henry Gibson, Tribune Printing Co. and C. K. Yost.
Ob Class Six, State Journal Co., Henry Gibson, Tribune Printing Co. and C. E. Yost.
On Class Seven. State Journal Co.. Henry GKbaoft, Tribune Printing Co. and ( . B. Yost.
The bids from the following tirius
On Class One, Tribune Printing Co. Lincoln, Neb. On Class Two, Henry Gibson, Omaha, N'eb. On Class Three, State Journal Co. Lincoln, Neb.

UEPORT OF THK
Oa Clan Five, Stele Journal Co., Lincoln, Neb. On Cl . Tribune Printing Co., Lincoln, Neb On Claw Seven, State Journal Co., Lincoln. Xel>.
wire on examination found to contain the lowest bids tor their
respective classes, the award was so made and a contract entered into accordingly with the parties on behalf of the 8tete.
The prices under the present contracts, m bich an- now in force will be observed to be considerably below those made by the
State tor the former term of years, thus enabling the State to very materially reduce its expenses in this direction.
Notwithstanding this favorable showing 1 , it is confidently hoped that the forthcoming Legislature will take such steps as will bring about a thorough revision, if not an entire repeal of the present printing law, and substitute in its place an enactment that will give to the State ¦ more practicable and common sense law than the State is now operating under.
Mv recommendations in the premises in view of this anticipated legislation, are as follow* :
First. That under the proposed law, that proposals be asked for on all forms of blanks, complete, at a stated price per quire, paper to be of required weight aud substance.
Second. That proposals be asked for on all work specified .is laws, journal-, pamphlet work, etc., at a stated price per page, the price mentioned to include all labor and material necessary to publish the work in complete form.
Third. That propo—ln be asked for on all blank book work at a stated price per quire, with a fixed price extra where a printed head or page is required, the price mentioned to include ail labor and material necessary to complete the book.
Fourth. That proposals be asked foron all bills and resolutions, or other matter to be printed for the House of the Legislature in bill form at a stated price per page, each page to contain a certain amount of matter. Yea and nay lists to be furnished at a stated

K. RKTaHY 01 BTAT1
Fifth. Requiring the several departments to prepare and submit at a stated time u sample of all work n— dec* for their respective offices for a given period to the Secretary- of State tor exhibit under the proposals that may be invited thereon.
Sixth. To continue the present Printing Board of Audit with
% general supervisory powt
The duties now devolving upon the Printing Board of .Yudit, under the operations of the present law, are such as should naturally fall to experts in this particular line of public business, and not to public officials who are wholly unexperienced in this direction as the {.(resent law would seem to contemplate, as it eannot be expected that these officers who compose the Printing Board from one administration to another, can have more than a mere superficial knowledge of their several duties as now imposed, to meet this matter in the interest of the public good, the remedy is suggested as aforesaid, embodying in the legislation suggested a practicable solution of the whole matter involved, and it is believed that if such an enactment can be had embracing the general features just mentioned to Your Excellency,, that as a result thereof, better prices and work can be obtained for the State, and a more intelligent understanding can always be arrived at between all parties concerned.

NOTARIES PUBLIC.
This subject has been referred to again at this time more particularly to bring to your Excellency's notice, the pressing and urgent need of an increase in the number of these officers in the several counties of this State, and the hope is expressed that adequate relief will be afforded in this direction at the forthcoming session of the Legislature.
I The '{uota of these officers for the several counties is at the jflent time limited to three for each one thousand inhabitants each county, the same being estimated upon the basis of six reons for every vote cast for the office of Governor at the State ction, provision is also made that each county may have not s than twelve notaries public.
I The quota on these appointments for the past two years, haa in based upon the vote cast for Governor in our State at the ction of 1880. By comparing this vote with aiat of the vote cast the present year, and under which a new quota will be made, will be observed that bat a slight increase has taken place, lile on the other hand, as your Excellency is aware, the number applications for these appointments has more than doubled. ie relief needed to meet this pressing demand should be met by ? abolition of all limit in the number that each county shall :eive in the way of these appointments, thus allowing all who ly see tit to apply for these appointments, and who can bring s requisite indorsements in their favor, to receive a commission.
IFhe office of a notary public is not in itself profitable. Nothing latever attaches to it but the mere convenience that it affords the public, and as no valid reason can be advanced why their mbcr should be limited, I would therefore urge the enactment a law embracing the foregoing suggestions just made, as it is own that the results that will follow will better subserve the blic interests of the State.

Tin.' table embraces all corporations commencing busiiii Nebraska during the past two years, both a? to railroad corporations and corporations of a miscellaneous character, and will be found of interest to all concerned.

Referring, however, d much of tljo subject as this office is directly interested in, I lid my that the fee tor this work should be increased by pi* - the charter fee «>n railroads at ten dollars, and the fee for tan "ii miscellaneous corporations at rive dollars, this fee to ude tlie filing and recording of the certificate and articles of irporation.

I Agreeably to a constitutional and statutory provision it is made B doty ot the Secretary of State in conjunction with the Auditor Public Accounts, to examine all bonds of the kind aforesaid.
I are submitted to them, and itj the same are found upon examition to have been issued pursuant to law, then to add their titi.are to that etfcvt. By reference to the accompanying table will be noticed that holders of these classes of our county
turities have availed themselves, to a very liberal extent, of the vantages accruing to them under this just and wise provision our laws.
And it is but proper to add in this connection, that since the enactment of the several laws bearing upon this subject, that the salutary effect made thereby upon our securities has been more than once commended by the leading financial agents of our country, and it is believed now that with the safeguards which are thrown around the issuance of these securities, that in
t future, the bogus and reckless peculation of adventurers will e, and that these Nebraska securities will occupy a place in money markets equal to the best and most approved secur" extant.

CONCLUSION This report will bring to a close to a great extent my duties as Secretary of State, and it is with pleasure that the opportunity affords itself of returning to your Excellency my most earnest and sincere thanks for the thoughtful consideration you have always bestowed upon the public business of this office that has been brought to your official attention during your admin; tion of the affairs of this State as the Chief Executive.
It is also but fitting to acknowledge frith grateful recognition, the many official courtesies received from the other State officials. and in so doing the hope is confidentially expressed that by this pleasant interchange of duties, much good to the public service has accrued therefrom.
